Michael McCarty Mark Konz Amy Vokal
Tony Talamantez Jeff Johnson Jeff Bengtson Linda Hilligoss
SUBJ: Site Plan/Traffic Advisory Committee Meeting – Tuesday, October 7, 2014
There will be a meeting of the Site Plan/Traffic Advisory Committee on Tuesday,
October 7, 2014 at 1:00 P.M. in the Minnesota Valley Conference Room. The following
items will be reviewed at the meeting.
1. Amended Preliminary Plat, Final Plat, Vacate a 30-Foot Drainage and Utility
Easement, Amended Planned Unit Development – Allow for Apartment Buildings
in the R-2, One and Two-Family Dwelling District – Cardinal Creek, LLC –
Outlot B, Cardinal Creek (Vicinity of Redtail Court and Tanager Road)
2. Certificate of Design Compliance and Conditional Use Permit to Allow for a
Restaurant with Drive-Thru in the B-3, Highway Business District – Tim Stevens
– Vicinity of Haefner Drive and Adams Street
3. Final Plat, Rezoning – Cougar East – Independent School District No. 77, Nourie
Properties, Inc., and Drummer Development – Vicinity of Hoffman Road and
4. Amended Preliminary Plat – Bridge Plaza – Mike Brennan, Brennan Companies –
Vicinity of N. Riverfront Drive and E. Plum Street
5. Amended Certificate of Design Compliance – Mixed-Use Building to be Located
in the Downtown Gateway Overlay District – Tailwind Real Estate, LLC – 520 S.
6. Rezoning - The Quarters (Formerly Campus Town Homes) – Growth Holdings,
LLC and Tailwind Oak Marsh, LLC – Area North of Timberwolf Drive and West
7. Site Plan – Alliance Contracting – Vicinity of Excel Drive and Victory Drive
8. Site Plan – YMCA Skate Park – Vicinity of Balcerzak Drive and Jaycee Court
9. Site Plan – Firearms Range Adjacent to Wastewater Treatment Plant – Pine Street
2. Traffic Control – Liberty Street & S. Front Street
3. Traffic Control – Yield Signs, Heron Drive & Falcon Drive
4. Discussion - Non-Breakaway Mail Box Support Structures – City Code 6.161
6. Discussion – Parking on Agency Road Area
7. Discussion – Parking Exemptions for Delivery Vehicles
The COG Report for September will be added to packet and sent separately to
If you have any questions regarding the items, please contact me at extension 571.

• Open • Neighborly

page.text: Present: Jon Noerenberg, Amy Vokal, Pam Hermanson, Paul Vogel, Larry Wasmund, Tony
Talamantez, Joe Grabianowski, Mark Konz, Rick Baird, Jeff Bengston, Jeff Johnson, Michael
McCarty, Chris Cain, Landon Bode, Parker Skophammer
Prior to the meeting Mr. Vogel noted a change for the Committee review process. Only major
issues will now be discussed for the Site Plan portion of the meeting. Full sets of plans would be
available for review in the Community Development Department, for review and submittal of
typed comments by any Committee member. Mr. Vogel asked that any members wishing to
review and comment submit any comments to Mr. Noerenberg by the Thursday following the

midpoint of the pond.

or other provision should be made to keep access clear.
15. Access to the pond over the outlet pipe should be constructed.
16. ADA parking and access shall be depicted.

page.text: Mr. Skophammer gave an overview of the licensing proposal. He advised that he had surveyed
other communities, including Duluth and Rochester, to determine what they have done for
licensing. Mr. Skophammer noted that the proposal allows for food trucks to operate in a 2-hour
parking stall for the posted two hours, and that food trucks and carts must be located at least 200
feet from a restaurant. There is no limitation as to how close food carts or trucks could be to
each other as long as the distance to the restaurant is maintained.
The Committee raised questions about the applicability to residential districts and private
property. Mr. Skophammer noted that locating on private property is allowed with the owner’s
permission. Locating in residential districts is not allowed. Food must be prepared in the truck
or cart and may not be made and loaded ahead of time.
Discussion by the Committee noted that it seemed that between the proposed requirements, and
the requirement that the food trucks have a commercial grade grease-laden hood. It was also
discussed how an event such as Songs on the Lawn and the Hy-Vee barbecue trailer on S.
Riverfront would be treated under the requirements, and how food vendors have thus far been
treated in locating in the parks with permit from the park superintendent. The Committee
suggested a “community event exclusion” clause to allow for special events.
The Committee also discussed how the licensing would be enabled, and whether it would be a
policy or ordinance and what department would be responsible for the licensing.
The Committee recommended that Mr. Skophammer discuss the options for licensing further
with the City Manager’s office for potential review by the City Center Partnership.
Mr. Vogel advised that the Mass Transit Project would be available for review in the Community
Four Way Stop – James Ave and Fairfield Ave
Mr. Vogel and Mr. Johnson noted that this project should be tied to what the adjacent school
does on their site. Mr. Johnson advised putting down road tubes on the Fairfield Avenue area for
Mr. Johnson recommended that the item be tabled until traffic counts are obtained and discussion
with the school for their plans can occur.
Reverse Angle Parking on Holly Lane
Mr. Johnson noted that the area would be resurfaced and that the property owner would be
adding his piece on. The area would also be re-curbed. Mr. McCarty added that they would also
be finishing the sidewalk down to Holly Lane.
There was discussion about the improvement of the Holly Lane and the work should be
Front Street and Area Parking Control
Mr. Bode gave information about proposed improvements, including posting of parking for
taxicab only from 5PM-5AM, and commercial parking only from 5AM-5PM.
Mr. Johnson added that Cheryl Lindquist has reminded taxi companies to park in the designated
taxi stalls. The project is part of the City Center Partnership Connectivity Plan.
The Committee recommended approval of the changes.
License to Encroach - 229 W. Pleasant Street Retaining Wall
The Committee recommended approval of the request.
The Committee had concerns with anticipated problems with snow removal. Engineering staff
will review and suggest alternatives. Engineering staff will contact the applicant’s design (Greg
There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned at 3:00 PM.
The City of Mankato Planning Commission will hold a public hearing regarding the following requests on
Wednesday, October 22, 2014 at 6:30 p.m., in the Mankato Room located on the first floor of the
Intergovernmental Center, 10 Civic Center Plaza, Mankato, MN. The purpose of this hearing is to
** Request of Matthew Melvin for an interim use permit to allow construction a second single-family
dwelling on a single lot in the Rural Conservation District. The subject property is described as
Tract Lying Between County Road 5 and railroad in the Northeast Quarter of the Southwest Quarter
of Section 20, Township 109 North, Range 26 West (23934 Third Avenue).
Request of Jordan Sands, LLC for an interim use permit to allow processing of industrial sand at
the wet processing plant on Sundays commencing October 26, 2014 and concluding on November
23, 2014. The subject property is described as parts of Section 29, 30, 31, and 32, Lime Township
(T109N, R26W), Blue Earth County, Minnesota. The subject property is described as parts of
Section 29, 30, 31, and 32, Lime Township (T109N, R26W), Blue Earth County, Minnesota (Lime

easement within Outlot H and Outlot B, Cardinal Creek. The property is described as Outlot B,

Request of Tailwind Real Estate, LLC for an amended Certificate of Design Compliance for a

Block 1, City Center Addition (520 S. Front Street).

APPLICATION OF EROSION PREVENTION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL BMP'S WHO WILL OVERSEE THE

IMPERVIOUS SURFACE IS CREATED ARE CHECKED BELOW:
[ ] WET SEDIMENTATION BASIN [ ] INFILTRATION / FILTRATION [ ] INLET SUMP

WATER FROM SITE WILL BE CONVEYED TO AN EXISTING DETENTION FACILITY ADJACENT TO THE SOUTH
BOUNDARY OF THE SITE. THE DETENTION FACILITY DISCHARGES TO A DRAINAGE DITCH AND EVENTUALLY

SHALL BE TAKEN TO PROTECT ANY WETLAND INTEGRITY. THIS PROJECT HAS NOT BEEN REVIEWED BY AN
CONSTRUCTION OF PERIMETER EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL AND INLET PROTECTION
SHALL BE COMPLETED BEFORE OTHER CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITY OCCURS.
USE PHASED CONSTRUCTION WHEREVER PRACTICAL AND ESTABLISH TURF AS SOON AS
TURF ESTABLISHMENT OR TEMPORARY SEEDING OF ALL EXPOSED SOIL NOT BEING ACTIVELY
WORKED SHOULD BE PRACTICED FOLLOWING THE STORM WATER POLLUTION PREVENTION
ALL EXPOSED SOILS SHALL BE SEEDED OR SODDED AT THE EARLIEST POSSIBLE TIME TO
A. SEED SHALL BE MNDOT MIXTURE 60B AND SHALL BE PLACED IN ACCORDANCE WITH MNDOT
2575. SEED SHALL MEET MNDOT SPECIFICATION 3876 AND BE APPLIED AT A RATE OF 100
LB/ACRE. MULCH SHALL BE MNDOT 3882 TYPE 3 MULCH. MULCH SHALL BE APPLIED AT A RATE
OF 2 TONS/ACRE. MULCH SHALL BE DISC ANCHORED. FERTILIZER SHALL BE APPLIED TO
SEEDED AREAS INCIDENTAL TO SEEDING. FERTILIZER SHALL BE A 10-10-20 (%N-P-K) APPLIED
ADDITIONAL EROSION PREVENTION MEASURES MAY BE FOUND IN THE PERMIT AND MPCA'S
DISTURBED GROUND MUST BE STABILIZED DURING COLD WEATHER WHEN FINAL
STABILIZATION AND GROWTH WILL NOT TAKE PLACE UNTIL THE NEXT GROWING SEASON.
STRAW IS THE MULCH MOST COMMONLY USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH SEEDING. THE STRAW
MULCH MAY BE SPREAD BY HAND OR WITH A MULCH BLOWER. STRAW MAY BE LOST TO WIND
AND MUST BE CHEMICALLY OR MECHANICALLY ANCHORED TO THE SOIL IMMEDIATELY AFTER
IT IS SPREAD. THE FOLLOWING METHODS OF ANCHORING MULCH MAY BE USED:
A MULCH-ANCHORING TOOL: IS A TRACTOR-DRAWN IMPLEMENT DESIGNED TO PUNCH MULCH
INTO THE SOIL. A MULCH-ANCHORING TOOL PROVIDES MAXIMUM EROSION CONTROL WITH
STRAW. A REGULAR FARM DISC, WEIGHTED AND SET NEARLY STRAIGHT, MAY BE USED
INSTEAD, BUT IT WILL NOT DO A JOB COMPARABLE TO THE MULCH-ANCHORING TOOL. THE
DISK SHOULD NOT BE SHARP ENOUGH TO CUT THROUGH THE STRAW. THESE METHODS ARE
LIMITED TO SLOPES NO STEEPER THAN 3:1, WHERE EQUIPMENT CAN OPERATE SAFELY.
A TACKIFIER IS A CHEMICAL BINDER THAT SECURES MULCH TO SOIL. APPLICATION OF
TACKIFIER SHOULD BE HEAVIEST AT THE EDGES OF AREAS AND AT CRESTS OF RIDGES AND
BANKS, TO RESIST WIND. THE TACKIFIER SHOULD BE APPLIED UNIFORMLY TO THE REST OF
THE AREA. A TACKIFIER MAY BE APPLIED AFTER THE MULCH HAS BEEN SPREAD OR IT MAY BE
SPRAYED INTO THE MULCH AS THE MULCH IS BEING BLOWN ONTO THE SOIL. APPLYING
STRAW AND A TACKIFIER TOGETHER IS THE MOST EFFECTIVE METHOD. LIQUID BINDERS
INCLUDE LATEX, GUAR GUM, PROTEINS AND AN ARRAY OF COMMERCIALLY AVAILABLE
SYNTHETIC BINDERS. ENVIRONMENTALLY INCOMPATIBLE PRODUCTS, SUCH AS TOXIC
MATERIALS, SHOULD NOT BE USED. ASPHALT-BASED PRODUCTS ARE NOT ALLOWED IN SOME
NETTING IS OFTEN USED TO KEEP STRAW MULCH IN PLACE UNTIL VEGETATION BECOMES
SYNTHETIC NET IS MOST COMMONLY USED, BUT JUTE NETS ARE USEFUL IN CHANNEL AND
CRITICAL-AREA STABILIZATION. NETS SHOULD BE BIODEGRADABLE, AND DEGRADE WITHIN SIX
MONTHS. NETS ARE NOT DESIGNED TO PROVIDE MOISTURE-CONSERVATION BENEFITS OR
EROSION PROTECTION. THEREFORE, THEY ARE USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH ORGANIC
IN CRITICAL AREAS, NETTING SHOULD ALWAYS BE INSTALLED OVER THE MULCH. HYDRAULIC
MULCHES, SUCH AS WOOD FIBER, MAY BE SPRAYED ON TOP OF AN INSTALLED NET. INSTALL
NETTING AND MATTING IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE MANUFACTURER'S INSTRUCTIONS.
CONSTRUCTION OF PERIMETER SEDIMENT AND EROSION CONTROL MEASURES AND INLET
PROTECTION SHALL BE COMPLETE PRIOR TO LAND DISTURBING ACTIVITIES OCCUR.
SILT FENCE: SILT FENCE SHALL CONSIST OF A TEMPORARY WETMAL BARRIER FABRIC
ATTACHED TO AND SUPPORTED BY WOVEN WIRE AND WOOD OR STEEL POSTS AND
ENTRENCHED INTO THE GROUND. THE SILT FENCE SHALL CONFORM TO MNDOT SECTION
EROSION CONTROL BLANKET: EROSION CONTROL BLANKET SHALL COMPLY WITH MNDOT
SECTION 3885, CATEGORY 00, WOOD CELLULOSE 1S, NT, RD.
TURF REINFORCEMENT MAT: TURF REINFORCEMENT MATS SHALL COMPLY WITH MNDOT
A ROCK CONSTRUCTION ENTRANCE OR OTHER APPROVED ALTERNATIVE MUST BE
CONSTRUCTED AT THE ENTRY POINT TO THE PROJECT SITE. ROCK CONSTRUCTION
ENTRANCE MUST BE 50'X25' (MIN.) OF 2" - 4" CRUSHED ROCK, 8" DEEP.
INLET EROSION PROTECTION SHALL BE INSTALLED AND MAINTAINED UNTIL TURF OR
THE CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE TO CONTROL EROSION FROM LEAVING THE
CONSTRUCTION ZONE. ALL ERODED MATERIAL THAT LEAVES THE CONSTRUCTION ZONE
SHALL BE COLLECTED BY THE CONTRACTOR AND RETURNED TO THE SITE AT THE
ALL STREETS MUST BE SWEPT WHEN ANY TRACKING OCCURS.
DEWATER SEDIMENT-LADEN WATER TO SEDIMENTATION BASINS IF POSSIBLE, OR USE OTHER
BMP'S TO PREVENT EROSION WHEN DISCHARGING TO SURFACE WATERS. USE APPROPRIATE
ENERGY DISSIPATION MEASURES ON ALL DISCHARGES.
DEWATERING PRACTICES CANNOT CAUSE NUISANCE CONDITIONS, EROSION OR IN RECEIVING
CHANNELS OR INUNDATION OF WETLANDS RESULTING IN ADVERSE IMPACTS.
PROVIDE CONCRETE WASHOUT CONTAINER. THE WASHOUT AREA SHALL BE INSPECTED
DAILY TO ENSURE THAT ALL CONCRETE WASHING IS PROPERLY DISPOSED ON IN DESIGNATED
CONTAINMENT AREA. THE WASHOUT CONTAINMENT SHALL BE CLEANED WHEN 75% FULL AND
HARDENED CONCRETE SHALL BE REMOVED AND PROPERLY DISPOSED OF OFF SITE
(DUMPSTER APPROVED RUBBLE SITE OR LANDFILL). WATER FROM THE WASHOUT SHALL BE
REMOVED BY VACUUM TRUCK OR OTHERWISE HAULED FROM THE CONSTRUCTION SITE AND
DISPOSED OF IN A MANNER ACCEPTABLE TO THE MPCA.
I HEREBY CERTIFY THAT THIS PLAN
WAS PREPAREDBY ME OR UNDER MY
DIRECT SUPERVISION AND THAT I AM
ENGINEER UNDER THE LAWS OF THE
TO THE HONORABLE MAYOR AND MEMBERS OF THE CITY COUNCIL OF MANKATO,
The undersigned property owner/owners respectfully represent:
That the petitioners are fee owners of the following described property situated in the City of
Mankato, Blue Earth County, Minnesota, to wit:
Outlot B, Cardinal Creek, according to the plat thereof on file and of record with the Blue Earth
The petitioner is interested in having vacation of any interest the City may or may not have in the
following described utility easement, to wit:
That portion of the 30 foot wide Drainage and Utility Easement dedicated across Outlot H,
Wings Over White Oak Second Addition and later shown crossing Outlot B, Cardinal Creek,
according to the plats thereof on file and or record with the Blue earth County Recorder, the
center line of which is described as:
Commencing at the southeast corner of Outlot I, wings Over White Oak Second Addition; thence
North 00 degrees 00 minutes 56 seconds West (assumed bearing) along the east line of said
Outlot I, a distance of 72.94 feet; thence North 62 degrees 37 minutes 24 seconds West, along
the northeasterly line of said Outlot I, a distance of 60.45 feet to the point of intersection with the
center line of the 30 foot wide Drainage and Utility Easement to be vacated, said point being the
point of beginning; thence North 19 degrees 27 minutes 44 seconds east, along said easement
center line, 170.60 feet to the point of intersection with the southerly line of the existing 30 foot
wide Drainage and Utility easement running east and west across Outlot H, Wings Over White
Oak Second Addition, and there terminating.
The side lines of the 30 foot wide Drainage and Utility Easement being vacated are prolonged or
shortened to terminate on the westerly line of the existing 30 foot wide Drainage and Utility
Easement running northerly across Outlot I and on the southerly line of the existing 30 foot wide
Drainage and Utility easement running easterly across Outlot H, Wings Over White Oak Second
That the above described portion of this utility easement is not necessary for any public or private
utilities and, therefore, the vacation of the described portion of said utility easement would relieve
the City of any responsibility for maintenance or construction.
THEREFORE, the petitioner/petitioners respectfully request that a date for a hearing on this petition
be set and at such hearing a resolution be passed to vacate any interest the City may have in the
above described portion of said utility easement.
Subscribed and sworn to by me, a Notary Public, within and for said County, on this
The City Council, with the assistance of the City Planning Commission, has the exclusive power to vacate or discontinue
public streets, alleys, highways, or any portion thereof in the city, and public utility or access easements, but no such
vacation or discontinuance shall be granted or ordered by the Council except upon the verified petition, in writing, of one or
more of the owners of real property on that portion of such street, alley, or highway proposed to be vacated, or upon the
verified petition of the city’s Community Development Director. The petition shall state the reason for the vacation and
briefly describe the street, alley, highway, or portion thereof, to be vacated.
The petition shall be delivered to the Community Development Director, who will forward it to the City Planning
Commission, which will hold a hearing on the request and make a recommendation to the City Council.
It is the responsibility of the applicants to have all utility companies review the request for vacation to determine whether
utilities are located in the right-of-way or easement to be vacated. The petition for right-of-way or easement vacation shall
be accompanied by this form, along with a map of the proposed vacation, and brought to each utility listed below, to be
signed and an indication made as to the presence of utilities. If easements must be retained for utilities or access, the

text.b: applicant shall submit a drawing and a written description of the easements with this form.

*Maintenance Building may have 2 exterior doors as opposed to 3 as shown in rendering.
*Exterior design shall be substantially adhered to. Siding materials may be changed to match
main apartment buildings. Exterior colors may change. Garage doors may be changed.

AT SIDES AND ALL SPACE BETWEEN
SOD - SOD ALL AREAS DISTURBED BY
AREAS, AND PLANTING BEDS SHALL BE IRRIGATED.
PLANT BED EDGER - USE POLY EDGER
PLANTING BEDS - SHALL BE MULCHED WITH 3"
DEPTH HARDWOOD MULCH. DO NOT USE AN
UNDERLAYMENT. NO PLASTIC OR FILTER FABRIC.
- LANDSCAPE WORK TO BE COMPLETED AFTER
COMPLETION OF FINISH GRADING. FINISH GRADING BY
- LANDSCAPE CONTRACTOR WILL VISIT SITE BEFORE
SUBMITTING A BID. THIS WILL ALLOW FOR A MORE
- IF THERE IS A DISCREPANCY BETWEEN THE NUMBER
OF PLANTS OR AREAS INDICATED ON THE PLANT LIST
OR NOTES AND THOSE SHOWN ON THE PLAN, THE
NUMBERS OR AREAS SHOWN ON THE PLAN WILL BE
- ALL PLANTS AND MATERIALS SHALL COMPLY WITH
THE LATEST EDITION OF THE AMERICAN STANDARD
FOR NURSERY STOCK, AMERICAN ASSOCIATION OF
- ALL DECIDUOUS TREES MEASURED BY CALIPER
SHALL BE MEASURED AT A POINT 6" UP FROM THE
- ALL TREE TRUNKS SHALL BE SURROUNDED BY A
MINIMUM 2 FOOT RADIUS BED WITH 3 INCH DEPTH
- CONTAINER GROWN PLANTS WILL HAVE BEEN
PLANTED IN THE CONTAINER FOR A MINIMUM OF SIX
- ALL PLANTS WILL BE GUARANTEED FOR FULL

I HEREBY CERTIFY THAT THIS PLAN, SPECIFICATION, OR
REPORT WAS PREPARED BY ME OR UNDER MY DIRECT
SUPERVISION AND THAT I AM A DULY LICENSED
LANDSCAPE ARCHITECT UNDER THE LAWS OF THE
1.01 Landscape work includes, but is not limited to, removal of weeds, top
soil installation, soil preparation, installation of edging, installation of irrigation
system, planting of trees, shrubs, and groundcover, final grading, installation
of erosion control fabric, mulching, weed control, clean-up, and regular
maintenance during construction and the establishment period.
1.02 No part of this work shall be performed or installed in any location or
manner, which may endanger the health, safety, or welfare of the public now,
or in the future. Construction means, methods, techniques, sequencing, etc.,
are the sole responsibility of the Contractor.
1.03 The Contractor agrees that he/she shall assume sole and complete
responsibility for job site conditions during the course of construction of this
project, including safety of all persons and property; that this requirement
shall apply continuously and not be limited to normal working hours; and that
the contractor shall defend, indemnify, and hold the Owner and Landscape
Architect harmless from any and all liability, real or alleged, in connection
with the performance of work on this project, excepting for liability arising
from the sole negligence of the Owner or Landscape Architect.
1.04 The Contractor shall comply with all applicable rules, regulations, laws,
and ordinances imposed by Authorities having Jurisdiction over this project
1.05 Contractor shall immediately give written notice to the Landscape
Architect of conflict in any part of plans, notes, or specifications. Request
clarification from I&S Group as appropriate.
1.06.1 "Existing conditions" for the work as specified herein are based on the
work described in the I&S Group drawings, and on the assumption that the
work described in these drawings will be completed as described.
1.06.2 Immediately report discrepancies or variances between the existing
conditions and the I&S Group drawings in writing to the owner's
representative. If the Contractor begins work specified herein without the
notification to I&S Group, the Contractor thereby acknowledges acceptance
of the site "As-Is" and shall perform the work shown on the drawings and
specified herein in accordance with the accepted base bid.
1.07 Prior to construction, the Contractor shall be responsible for locating all
1.07.1 Existing utility lines to be removed which may not be shown on
construction drawings are presumed to be present within the Site. Contractor
shall not proceed with such utility lines removal. Contractor shall contact I&S
Group immediately upon discovery of an unidentified underground utility
piping. I&S Group will then direct the Contractor as to the appropriate action
1.08 Contractor shall avoid damage to utilities, structures, site
appurtenances, etc., which occur as a result of the landscape construction.
1.09 The Landscape Contractor is responsible for verifying all quantities
shown on these plans before pricing the work. Any difference in quantities
shall be brought to the attention of I&S Group for clarification.
1.10 All substitutions shall be requested in writing and shall be approved by
the I&S Group landscape architecture department, 507-387-6651.
1.11 If any areas which appear to need landscape installation, but are not
shown as landscaped on the plans, notify I&S Group landscape architecture
1.12 All registered chemicals used on this project shall be handled and
applied in accordance with all applicable laws, rules, and regulations.
1.13 Clean-up the site at completion of this work, leave the site in an
1.14 Upon completion of installation the contractor shall issue a Certificate of
Completion stating the project name and the following: "I, (state licensed
contractor's name) hereby certify, under penalty of perjury, that the
installation of landscape and irrigation for the above project is complete and
conforms with the city and owner approved plans and specifications, with the
exception of the following deviations (list approved deviations, and who
approved them)." The certificate shall be signed by the Contractor's license
1.15 Prior to starting installation the contractor shall confirm that the
construction set of plans are signed or stamped for approval by the city.
Notify the landscape architect immediately if a city approval stamp or
signature is not visible on the drawings.
2.01 The top 8 inches of soil shall be free of rocks, concrete, and foreign
materials larger than 2 inches in diameter. Road base material shall not be
present in the top 24 inches of soil. Any soil mixed with road base shall be
2.02 Final grades shall be smooth and even, providing an attractive
appearance. Concentrated flows of water shall not drain over walks. Contact
landscape architect if this appears unavoidable. Landscape materials shall
not block or interfere with the free flow of drainage water.
2.03 Planting areas shall slope at 2% minimum away from building
foundations and footings. Positive drainage shall be provided in all planting
areas. No standing water shall be permitted. A maximum grade difference of
1/2 inch shall be allowed between sidewalks or curbs and the finish surface in
2.04 The planting soil mixture specified for planters shall be free of clay and
is to be composed of topsoil and additional amendments and backfilled to a
depth of 24". Amend the top 8 inches of topsoil in all planted areas with the
following materials. Quantities are minimums per 1000 square feet.
2.04.1 [3] cubic yards of nitrolized compost. Compost shall have a 1/2 inch
maximum particle size, a ph of 6.5 or higher, shall be cured for 60 days or
more after composting, shall meet all EPA guidelines, and shall be weed and
2.05 All planting areas, including areas to be sodded, shall receive the
following soil preparation prior to planting: a minimum of 8 inches of lightly
compacted topsoil shall be installed over the subsoil if topsoil has been
removed or is not present. If topsoil filters down into the subsoil, additional
topsoil shall be applied until a stable 8 inch deep layer of topsoil is
maintained. The top 8 inches of topsoil in the planters shall be machine-tilled
to aerate the soil and alleviate any surface compaction.
2.06 The burden of proof of soil amendment installation rests with the
Contractor. Soil tests may be required at the Contractor's expense in order
3.01 Rough grading shall be completed prior to the start of planting in any
given area of the project site.
3.03 Plants shall be well branched and bushy with good color, plant size
should be in proportion to the pot as described by the American Standard for
Nursery Stock. Plants delivered to the site that are yellow, sparse, burned,
or barren will be rejected. Plant pots shall have soil to within 1 inch of the rim
and the plants shall be fully rooted in the container. Plant material with
cracked or broken root-balls shall be removed from the site. All plants shall
be high quality with a securely attached id tag, have normal growth and
should be free from disease, insects, or insect eggs. Plants shall conform
with the minimum standards of ANSI z60 - the American Standard for
Nursery Stock. Trees may not have been topped (upright branches at top of
may not be cut or pruned).
3.04 Plants shall exceed the minimum size at planting requirements noted
on the plans, regardless of the size of the container. No exceptions. Prepare
bids based on the plant size, not the container size. A larger container size
plant may be required to meet the plant size minimums. No cost adjustments
will be allowed for use of larger container plants. Measurements shall be
made with the plant in a natural, unsupported position.
3.05 Plants specified as "gallon," "container," or "box" on the plans shall
conform to the ANSI z60, American Standard for Nursery Stock requirements
for sizes with equivalent numbers (#1, #5, #15, #24, etc.,) as if specified as
such on the plans. Thus a plant labeled as "5 gallon" size on the plans must
be equivalent to a #5 container size plant as described in the American
3.06 Tree calipers shall be measured 6 inches above the rootball per ANSI
z60, American Standard for Nursery Stock. Tree heights shall be measured
from top of rootball to top of highest branch.
3.07 Trees shall be planted 4'0" or more from hardscapes, such as
sidewalks, foundations, curbs, patios, etc. when possible.
3.08 Trees shall not be planted within 4'0" of buried utility lines, relocate
trees slightly, if not possible notify landscape architect.
3.09 A vertical clearance of 114 inches is required above all disabled
accessible parking spaces, a vertical clearance of 80 inches is required
above all walkways. Trim trees to remove all limbs within these areas for
3.10 Turf areas shall be sloped as required to provide positive drainage to
the perimeter, or to drain inlets. Turf shall be installed flush with the top of
surrounding curbs and walks so as to prevent water from puddling at the turf
edges, import top soil if necessary to comply with this requirement.
3.11 All sod turf shall be rolled with a weighted roller after installation.
4.01 When rock mulch is indicated, install a 3" deep layer of 1"-2" dia. rock.
4.02 When rock mulch is indicated, place mulch onto a water permeable
filter fabric. Such fabric shall be of substantial quality and include a
manufacturer warranty of a minimum of 10 years.
4.03 When wood mulch is indicated, install premium shredded hardwood
mulch to a minimum depth of 3 inches. All mulched areas shall also
incorporate a granular pre-emergent herbicide, such as Preen, to aid in weed
abatement. No permeable filter fabric should be used unless called for on the
5.01 See grading plans for slopes locations and gradients
5.02 Notify the landscape architect prior to starting work if any area on this
site is found to have a slope exceeding 3:1.
7.01 The Contractor shall maintain the landscape & irrigation throughout
construction and up to opening date.
7.02 The Contractor shall be responsible for maintaining a regular watering
schedule for all sodded areas for a minimum of 30 days after installation to
7.03 The Contractor shall take all reasonable precautions required to protect
plants throughout the maintenance period from abnormal temperatures.
8.01 The Contractor shall request a final observation by the owner's
8.02 Observation must be requested 7 days in advance of the anticipated
8.03 Prior to requesting the final observation it is the contractor's
responsibility to assure that the work is finished and complies with all clearly
stated requirements of the plans, including plant sizes and quantities.
Substantial non-compliance will result in the assessment of penalties against
the Contractor, to be not less than the cost of the observation. Any of the
following shall be considered proof of substantial non-compliance:
8.03.1 Installed quantity of any item is less than 95% of that specified.
8.03.2 More than 3% of any plant variety are undersize.
8.03.3 More than 3% of any plant variety are dead or dying. Dying is defined
as wilting or loss of more than 30% of leaves (deciduous leaf drop excepted.)
9.01 The Landscape Contractor shall guarantee all landscape work for a
period of time, beginning at the start of the maintenance period, as follows:
9.01.2 Shrubs, lawn and groundcover - one year.
9.02 Theft, vandalism, and death due to acts of God are excluded from this
